w:r.w:t: Introduction
The Lancet Global Health will also require a short paragraph for each of the following:
Evidence before this study:
we could use the now-cut paragraph about the three papers on abortions by age
Added value of this study
Implications of all the available evidence

Age-specific abortion rates are a key demographic indicator that can provide a clearer picture of the dynamics of abortion within a country and between countries and world regions. Understanding age patterns of abortion can serve as a proxy for understanding unintended pregnancy patterns, particularly in regions (such as Europe) where we lack robust unintended pregnancy measurement but have good abortion data
(cite)

. Age-specific abortion data can also help understand which populations face the highest burden of unintended pregnancy and abortion, and who would benefit the most from targeted contraceptive and reproductive health resources.
Prior research on age-specific abortion patterns is outdated and limited in geographic scope
(cite)
Recent shifts (changing abortion laws, contraceptive access, delayed childbearing, healthcare disruptions) make updated analysis timely.
Information about abortion within a country may be indicative of evolving reproductive health needs and behaviors of a population, from contraceptive access to fertility intentions
(cite).

A disproportionately high number of abortions in an age group may be indicative that this group has an above-average likelihood of experiencing an unintended pregnancy or of choosing an abortion to end a pregnancy
(cite Bankole 1999).

In recent decades, several factors influencing women’s age at the time of abortion have seen notable shifts worldwide. Many countries have liberalized their abortion laws and expanded access to abortion, while others have moved toward more regressive and restrictive laws

w:r.w:t: (Center for Reproductive Rights 2025;
Maputo Protocol at 2-: Progress on Abortion Rights in Africa
, n.d.; Boland and Katzive 2008)

Building on previous work on abortion by age, this descriptive study examines country-specific levels and trends of induced abortions by women’s age in countries with publicly available and reliable data from the early 2000s through 2024

ADDIN ZOTERO_ITEM CSL_CITATION {"citationID":"eFHVcGej","properties":{"formattedCitation":"(Bankole et al. 1999; Sedgh et al. 2012; Chae et al. 2017)","plainCitation":"(Bankole et al. 1999; Sedgh et al. 2012; Chae et al. 2017)","noteIndex":0},"citationItems":[{"id":58374,"uris":["http://zotero.org/users/9607907/items/6SZZHFFI"],"itemData":{"id":58374,"type":"article-journal","container-title":"International Family Planning Perspectives","issue":"2","title":"Characteristics of women who obtain induced abortion: a worldwide review","URL":"https://www.guttmacher.org/sites/default/files/article_files/2506899.pdf","volume":"25","author":[{"family":"Bankole","given":"Akinrinola"},{"family":"Singh","given":"Susheela"},{"family":"Haas","given":"Taylor"}],"issued":{"date-parts":[["1999",6]]}}},{"id":58087,"uris":["http://zotero.org/users/9607907/items/7FLL36P7"],"itemData":{"id":58087,"type":"article-journal","abstract":"CONTEXT: Assessments of abortion levels and trends by women's age at termination can be used to monitor trends in unintended pregnancy by age and can inform relevant programs and policies.
METHODS: Legal abortion incidence data were compiled from national statistical offices and nationally representative surveys of more than 40 countries where legal abortion is generally available. Age-specific abortion rates and percentage distributions of abortions by age were computed, and trends since 1996 and 2003 were examined. Subregional and regional estimates were developed for geographic areas where the majority of the population was represented by the data.
RESULTS: The median year for the most recent estimates of abortions by woman's age was 2009. Adolescents accounted for a smaller share of abortions than their share of the population in the majority of eligible countries with data. In most countries, the highest age-specific abortion rates and proportions of abortions were among women aged 20-29. Since 1996, adolescent abortion rates have increased the most in Belgium, the Netherlands and Scotland (22-42%), and have decreased the most in Estonia, Hungary, Iceland, Slovakia and Slovenia (40-55%). The proportion of abortions obtained by adolescents was higher in North America (18%) than in Europe overall (11%), although the proportion in Northern Europe (18%) was the same as that in North America.
CONCLUSIONS: Higher abortion rates in particular age-groups probably reflect higher-than-average levels of unmet need for contraception or difficulty using methods consistently and effectively, and a stronger desire to avoid childbearing. Each of the patterns observed has implications for service and information needs within countries.","container-title":"International Perspectives on Sexual and Reproductive Health","DOI":"10.1363/3814312","ISSN":"1944-0405","issue":"3","journalAbbreviation":"Int Perspect Sex Reprod Health","language":"eng","note":"PMID: 23018136","page":"143-153","source":"PubMed","title":"Legal abortion levels and trends by woman's age at termination","volume":"38","author":[{"family":"Sedgh","given":"Gilda"},{"family":"Bankole","given":"Akinrinola"},{"family":"Singh","given":"Susheela"},{"family":"Eilers","given":"Michelle"}],"issued":{"date-parts":[["2012",9]]}}},{"id":58021,"uris":["http://zotero.org/users/9607907/items/ZXQ7HWCY"],"itemData":{"id":58021,"type":"article-journal","abstract":"BACKGROUND: In 2010-2014, approximately 86% of abortions took place in low- and middle-income countries (LMICs). Although abortion incidence varies minimally across geographical regions, it varies widely by subregion and within countries by subgroups of women. Differential abortion levels stem from variation in the level of unintended pregnancies and in the likelihood that women with unintended pregnancies obtain abortions.
OBJECTIVES: To examine the characteristics of women obtaining induced abortions in LMICs.
METHODS: We use data from official statistics, population-based surveys, and abortion patient surveys to examine variation in the percentage distribution of abortions and abortion rates by age at abortion, marital status, parity, wealth, education, and residence. We analyze data from five countries in Africa, 13 in Asia, eight in Europe, and two in Latin America and the Caribbean (LAC).
RESULTS: Women across all sociodemographic subgroups obtain abortions. In most countries, women aged 20-29 obtained the highest proportion of abortions, and while adolescents obtained a substantial fraction of abortions, they do not make up a disproportionate share. Region-specific patterns were observed in the distribution of abortions by parity. In many countries, a higher fraction of abortions occurred among women of high socioeconomic status, as measured by wealth status, educational attainment, and urban residence. Due to limited data on marital status, it is unknown whether married or unmarried women make up a larger share of abortions.
CONCLUSIONS: These findings help to identify subgroups of women with disproportionate levels of abortion, and can inform policies and programs to reduce the incidence of unintended pregnancies; and in LMICs that have restrictive abortion laws, these findings can also inform policies to minimize the consequences of unsafe abortion and motivate liberalization of abortion laws. Program planners, policymakers, and advocates can use this information to improve access to safe abortion services, postabortion care, and contraceptive services.","container-title":"PloS One","DOI":"10.1371/journal.pone.0172976","ISSN":"1932-6203","issue":"3","journalAbbreviation":"PLoS One","language":"eng","note":"PMID: 28355285
PMCID: PMC5371299","page":"e0172976","source":"PubMed","title":"Characteristics of women obtaining induced abortions in selected low- and middle-income countries","volume":"12","author":[{"family":"Chae","given":"Sophia"},{"family":"Desai","given":"Sheila"},{"family":"Crowell","given":"Marjorie"},{"family":"Sedgh","given":"Gilda"},{"family":"Singh","given":"Susheela"}],"issued":{"date-parts":[["2017"]]}}}],"schema":"https://github.com/citation-style-language/schema/raw/master/csl-citation.json"}

w:r.w:t: (Bankole et al. 1999; Sedgh et al. 2012; Chae et al. 2017)

. Specifically, we assess how the distribution of abortions across age groups has changed, how age-specific abortion rates differ between adolescents and older women, and investigate whether the dynamics of abortions by age vary by region and sub-region.

Tracking age-specific abortion rates is essential for identifying which populations face the highest burden of unintended pregnancy and abortion, who would benefit the most from targeted reproductive health resources, and what factors are driving overall abortion incidence.

A disproportionately high number of abortions in an age group may be indicative that this group has an above-average likelihood of experiencing an unintended pregnancy or of choosing an abortion to end a pregnancy (cite Bankole 1999).
Recommendation: Streamline to 3-4 concise sentences that establish: (1) why age matters substantively, (2) the data gap we're filling, and (3) why now is an important time for this analysis.
In addition, age at first birth and rates of delayed childbearing have risen in upper-middle- and high-income countries

w:r.w:t: (Eurostat 2025; Brown et al. 2025)

w:r.w:delText: Tracking the worldwide incidence of abortion in recent decades has been crucial for informing and improving sexual and reproductive health policies, monitoring trends and progress, and identifying health disparities between regions and countries. Since 1990, global abortion rates initially declined, following the trajectory of unintended pregnancy rates, before rising again
as the proportion of unintended pregnancies ending in abortion increased.
As a result, global abortion rates in 1990-1994 and 2015-2019 were roughly equal
w:r.w:delInstrText: ADDIN ZOTERO_ITEM CSL_CITATION {"citationID":"XyoJ1Xa8","properties":{"formattedCitation":"(Bearak et al. 2020a)","plainCitation":"(Bearak et al. 2020a)","noteIndex":0},"citationItems":[{"id":58139,"uris":["http://zotero.org/users/9607907/items/295MGF63"],"itemData":{"id":58139,"type":"article-journal","container-title":"The Lancet Global Health","DOI":"10.1016/S2214-109X(20)30315-6","ISSN":"2214109X","issue":"9","journalAbbreviation":"The Lancet Global Health","language":"en","page":"e1152-e1161","source":"DOI.org (Crossref)","title":"Unintended pregnancy and abortion by income, region, and the legal status of abortion: estimates from a comprehensive model for 1990–2019","title-short":"Unintended pregnancy and abortion by income, region, and the legal status of abortion","volume":"8","author":[{"family":"Bearak","given":"Jonathan"},{"family":"Popinchalk","given":"Anna"},{"family":"Ganatra","given":"Bela"},{"family":"Moller","given":"Ann-Beth"},{"family":"Tunçalp","given":"Özge"},{"family":"Beavin","given":"Cynthia"},{"family":"Kwok","given":"Lorraine"},{"family":"Alkema","given":"Leontine"}],"issued":{"date-parts":[["2020",9]]}}}],"schema":"https://github.com/citation-style-language/schema/raw/master/csl-citation.json"}

w:r.w:delText: However, marked variations by country income level and abortion legality have been observed, with high-income countries and countries where abortion is broadly available having generally lower unintended pregnancy and abortion rates compared to low- and middle-income countries or countries where abortion is restricted

ADDIN ZOTERO_ITEM CSL_CITATION {"citationID":"aFqtU1DO","properties":{"formattedCitation":"(Sedgh et al. 2016; Bearak et al. 2020a)","plainCitation":"(Sedgh et al. 2016; Bearak et al. 2020a)","noteIndex":0},"citationItems":[{"id":58136,"uris":["http://zotero.org/users/9607907/items/IFM2T6ZK"],"itemData":{"id":58136,"type":"article-journal","abstract":"BACKGROUND: Information about the incidence of induced abortion is needed to motivate and inform efforts to help women avoid unintended pregnancies and to monitor progress toward that end. We estimate subregional, regional, and global levels and trends in abortion incidence for 1990 to 2014, and abortion rates in subgroups of women. We use the results to estimate the proportion of pregnancies that end in abortion and examine whether abortion rates vary in countries grouped by the legal status of abortion.
METHODS: We requested abortion data from government agencies and compiled data from international sources and nationally representative studies. With data for 1069 country-years, we estimated incidence using a Bayesian hierarchical time series model whereby the overall abortion rate is a function of the modelled rates in subgroups of women of reproductive age defined by their marital status and contraceptive need and use, and the sizes of these subgroups.
FINDINGS: We estimated that 35 abortions (90% uncertainty interval [UI] 33 to 44) occurred annually per 1000 women aged 15-44 years worldwide in 2010-14, which was 5 points less than 40 (39-48) in 1990-94 (90% UI for decline -11 to 0). Because of population growth, the annual number of abortions worldwide increased by 5.9 million (90% UI -1.3 to 15.4), from 50.4 million in 1990-94 (48.6 to 59.9) to 56.3 million (52.4 to 70.0) in 2010-14. In the developed world, the abortion rate declined 19 points (-26 to -14), from 46 (41 to 59) to 27 (24 to 37). In the developing world, we found a non-significant 2 point decline (90% UI -9 to 4) in the rate from 39 (37 to 47) to 37 (34 to 46). Some 25% (90% UI 23 to 29) of pregnancies ended in abortion in 2010-14. Globally, 73% (90% UI 59 to 82) of abortions were obtained by married women in 2010-14 compared with 27% (18 to 41) obtained by unmarried women. We did not observe an association between the abortion rates for 2010-14 and the grounds under which abortion is legally allowed.
INTERPRETATION: Abortion rates have declined significantly since 1990 in the developed world but not in the developing world. Ensuring access to sexual and reproductive health care could help millions of women avoid unintended pregnancies and ensure access to safe abortion.
FUNDING: UK Government, Dutch Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Norwegian Agency for Development Cooperation, The David and Lucile Packard Foundation, UNDP/UNFPA/UNICEF/WHO/World Bank Special Programme of Research, Development and Research Training in Human Reproduction.","container-title":"Lancet (London, England)","DOI":"10.1016/S0140-6736(16)30380-4","ISSN":"1474-547X","issue":"10041","journalAbbreviation":"Lancet","language":"eng","note":"PMID: 27179755
PMCID: PMC5498988","page":"258-267","source":"PubMed","title":"Abortion incidence between 1990 and 2014: global, regional, and subregional levels and trends","title-short":"Abortion incidence between 1990 and 2014","volume":"388","author":[{"family":"Sedgh","given":"Gilda"},{"family":"Bearak","given":"Jonathan"},{"family":"Singh","given":"Susheela"},{"family":"Bankole","given":"Akinrinola"},{"family":"Popinchalk","given":"Anna"},{"family":"Ganatra","given":"Bela"},{"family":"Rossier","given":"Clémentine"},{"family":"Gerdts","given":"Caitlin"},{"family":"Tunçalp","given":"Özge"},{"family":"Johnson","given":"Brooke Ronald"},{"family":"Johnston","given":"Heidi Bart"},{"family":"Alkema","given":"Leontine"}],"issued":{"date-parts":[["2016",7,16]]}}},{"id":58139,"uris":["http://zotero.org/users/9607907/items/295MGF63"],"itemData":{"id":58139,"type":"article-journal","container-title":"The Lancet Global Health","DOI":"10.1016/S2214-109X(20)30315-6","ISSN":"2214109X","issue":"9","journalAbbreviation":"The Lancet Global Health","language":"en","page":"e1152-e1161","source":"DOI.org (Crossref)","title":"Unintended pregnancy and abortion by income, region, and the legal status of abortion: estimates from a comprehensive model for 1990–2019","title-short":"Unintended pregnancy and abortion by income, region, and the legal status of abortion","volume":"8","author":[{"family":"Bearak","given":"Jonathan"},{"family":"Popinchalk","given":"Anna"},{"family":"Ganatra","given":"Bela"},{"family":"Moller","given":"Ann-Beth"},{"family":"Tunçalp","given":"Özge"},{"family":"Beavin","given":"Cynthia"},{"family":"Kwok","given":"Lorraine"},{"family":"Alkema","given":"Leontine"}],"issued":{"date-parts":[["2020",9]]}}}],"schema":"https://github.com/citation-style-language/schema/raw/master/csl-citation.json"}

w:r.w:delText: Additionally, within these contexts, the patterns in characteristics of women obtaining abortions vary considerably, as reproductive preferences and behaviors, including abortions, often vary across economic and demographic subgroups

ADDIN ZOTERO_ITEM CSL_CITATION {"citationID":"KV8AOZpJ","properties":{"formattedCitation":"(Ahinkorah 2021; Caserta et al. 2016; Requena M and Stanek M 2024)","plainCitation":"(Ahinkorah 2021; Caserta et al. 2016; Requena M and Stanek M 2024)","noteIndex":0},"citationItems":[{"id":58024,"uris":["http://zotero.org/users/9607907/items/AT43VL9Q"],"itemData":{"id":58024,"type":"article-journal","abstract":"Abstract
 
 Background
 Most of the unintended pregnancies that occur among adolescent girls and young women (AGYW) in sub-Saharan Africa (SSA) end up in pregnancy termination. In this study, the socio-demographic determinants of pregnancy termination among AGYW (aged 15–24) in selected countries with high fertility rates in SSA were examined.
 
 
 Methods
 
 This was a cross-sectional analysis of data from the most recent Demographic and Health Surveys of nine countries in SSA. The countries included are Angola, Burkina Faso, Burundi, Chad, Gambia, Mali, Niger, Nigeria, and Uganda. A total of 62,747 AGYW constituted the sample size for the study. Fixed and random effects models were used to examine the determinants of pregnancy termination with statistical significance at
 p

0.05.
 
 
 
 Results
 Higher odds of pregnancy termination were found among AGYW aged 20

24, those who were cohabiting and married, those who listened to radio and watched television at least once a week and those who lived in communities with high literacy level. Conversely, the odds of pregnancy termination were lower among AGYW with three or more births and those with secondary/higher education.
 
 
 Conclusion
 The socio-demographic determinants of pregnancy termination among AGYW in this study were age, level of education, marital status, exposure to radio and television, parity, and community literacy level. The findings provide the needed information for designing health interventions to reduce unwanted pregnancies and unsafe abortions in countries with high fertility rates in SSA. It is recommended that governments and non-governmental organisations in these countries should enhance sexuality education and regular sensitization of adolescent sexual and reproductive health programmes targeted at AGYW who are at risk of pregnancy termination.","container-title":"BMC Pregnancy and Childbirth","DOI":"10.1186/s12884-021-04064-1","ISSN":"1471-2393","issue":"1","journalAbbreviation":"BMC Pregnancy Childbirth","language":"en","page":"598","source":"DOI.org (Crossref)","title":"Socio-demographic determinants of pregnancy termination among adolescent girls and young women in selected high fertility countries in sub-Saharan Africa","volume":"21","author":[{"family":"Ahinkorah","given":"Bright Opoku"}],"issued":{"date-parts":[["2021",12]]}}},{"id":58074,"uris":["http://zotero.org/users/9607907/items/RBYSA6DB"],"itemData":{"id":58074,"type":"article-journal","abstract":"PURPOSE OF INVESTIGATION: The aim of this study was to analyze trends and attitudes towards abortion in Italian women in the last decades.
MATERIALS AND METHODS: The authors analyzed number, socio-economic trends, and major clinical-epidemiological features of induced abortion in Italy (1980-2009).
RESULTS: Up to 1996 abortion rates were higher among married women, but from 1996 to 2009 they were higher among single women. The reduction of abortions has been observed in all age-groups, except in women from 15 to 19 years of age. Abortions were higher among younger women, women without previous abortions, nulliparous women, women with junior and senior high school diplomas (2005-2006), women with an academic degree (2007-2009), and professional women. Conclu- sion: In Italy, despite the decrease of the abortion rates, voluntary termination of pregnancy is still present and the spread of contraception is scarce. More information about contraception is necessary to help lower the incidence of both unintended pregnancy and abortion.","container-title":"Clinical and Experimental Obstetrics & Gynecology","ISSN":"0390-6663","issue":"4","journalAbbreviation":"Clin Exp Obstet Gynecol","language":"eng","note":"PMID: 29734553","page":"578-583","source":"PubMed","title":"Attitudes towards abortion in Italian women: socio-economic trends and epidemiological features","title-short":"Attitudes towards abortion in Italian women","volume":"43","author":[{"family":"Caserta","given":"D."},{"family":"Matteucci","given":"E."},{"family":"Ralli","given":"E."},{"family":"Moscarini","given":"F."}],"issued":{"date-parts":[["2016"]]}}},{"id":1330,"uris":["http://zotero.org/groups/2295646/items/J6YYBA9B"],"itemData":{"id":1330,"type":"article-journal","abstract":"OBJECTIVE: Analyzing the variations in induced abortion (IA) rates across different subpopulations in Spain based on country of origin, while considering educational and age composition. METHOD: Using 2021 Voluntary Termination of Pregnancy register and 2021 Spanish Census microdata, we calculated crude IA rates and age-specific abortion rates. We used age-standardized IA rates (ASIAR) to account for the confounding effect of age composition. We compared seven subpopulations residing in Spain, taking into account simple ages and educational levels aggregated into four categories. RESULTS: Immigrant women, especially those from Sub-Saharan and Latin American countries, consistently had higher IA rates compared to native Spanish women. According to age-specific IA rates, university-educated women had considerably fewer abortions than women with other education levels at any age. Age-standardized rates stratified by migratory origin revealed that native Spanish women with primary education or less had higher IA rates than their immigrant counterparts. There was a clear non-linear, association between educational level and IA rates among immigrants. The highest propensity for IA was found among secondary school graduates, while university graduates had the lowest IA rate. CONCLUSIONS: The study demonstrated that variability in sociodemographic characteristics had an impact on IA rates. Young women with middle educational attainment and immigrant background had a higher likelihood of undergoing IA in Spain. The relationship between educational level and IA rates was complex, with variations observed among different groups and changes over time.","container-title":"Gac Sanit","DOI":"10.1016/j.gaceta.2024.102419","journalAbbreviation":"Gac Sanit","note":"publisher-place: Spain","page":"102419","title":"Differential rates of induced abortion in Spain: educational attainment and age among native and immigrant women.","volume":"38","author":[{"literal":"Requena M"},{"literal":"Stanek M"}],"issued":{"date-parts":[["2024"]]}}}],"schema":"https://github.com/citation-style-language/schema/raw/master/csl-citation.json"}

w:r.w:delText: Understanding patterns by subgroups, and in particular by age groups, is essential for identifying which populations face the highest burden of unintended pregnancy and abortion, and
who would benefit the most from targeted contraceptive and reproductive health resources.

A disproportionately high number of abortions in an age group may be indicative that this group has an above-average likelihood of experiencing an unintended pregnancy or of choosing an abortion to end a pregnancy
w:r.w:delInstrText: ADDIN ZOTERO_ITEM CSL_CITATION {"citationID":"yPW7qlpW","properties":{"formattedCitation":"(Bankole et al. 1999)","plainCitation":"(Bankole et al. 1999)","noteIndex":0},"citationItems":[{"id":58374,"uris":["http://zotero.org/users/9607907/items/6SZZHFFI"],"itemData":{"id":58374,"type":"article-journal","container-title":"International Family Planning Perspectives","issue":"2","title":"Characteristics of women who obtain induced abortion: a worldwide review","URL":"https://www.guttmacher.org/sites/default/files/article_files/2506899.pdf","volume":"25","author":[{"family":"Bankole","given":"Akinrinola"},{"family":"Singh","given":"Susheela"},{"family":"Haas","given":"Taylor"}],"issued":{"date-parts":[["1999",6]]}}}],"schema":"https://github.com/citation-style-language/schema/raw/master/csl-citation.json"}

w:r.w:delText: Such information can be also used to better understand the factors driving variations in overall abortion incidence, and to craft effective and equitable reproductive health policies and programs that meet the needs of all individuals. This evidence can
also contribute to informed public discourse around abortion and help reduce stigma by providing a data-driven picture of women who obtain abortions.

Prior global assessments of age patterns of abortion are limited and increasingly outdated. In 1999, Bankole et al analyzed data from 1981-1996 in all countries with available data, and found that globally, abortion rates were generally highest among women in their twenties, but adolescents often accounted for a higher proportion of abortions per known pregnancies than women in their twenties
w:r.w:delInstrText: ADDIN ZOTERO_ITEM CSL_CITATION {"citationID":"KHIaH2b2","properties":{"formattedCitation":"(Bankole et al. 1999)","plainCitation":"(Bankole et al. 1999)","noteIndex":0},"citationItems":[{"id":58374,"uris":["http://zotero.org/users/9607907/items/6SZZHFFI"],"itemData":{"id":58374,"type":"article-journal","container-title":"International Family Planning Perspectives","issue":"2","title":"Characteristics of women who obtain induced abortion: a worldwide review","URL":"https://www.guttmacher.org/sites/default/files/article_files/2506899.pdf","volume":"25","author":[{"family":"Bankole","given":"Akinrinola"},{"family":"Singh","given":"Susheela"},{"family":"Haas","given":"Taylor"}],"issued":{"date-parts":[["1999",6]]}}}],"schema":"https://github.com/citation-style-language/schema/raw/master/csl-citation.json"}

w:r.w:delText: In 2012, Sedgh et al examined trends between the mid-1990s and late 2000s in countries with liberal abortion laws, finding that adolescents accounted for a smaller share of abortions relative to their population size in many countries, while abortion rates were highest among women in the mid-range of their reproductive years
w:r.w:delInstrText:
ADDIN ZOTERO_ITEM CSL_CITATION {"citationID":"V4w5kmO4","properties":{"formattedCitation":"(Sedgh et al. 2012)","plainCitation":"(Sedgh et al. 2012)","noteIndex":0},"citationItems":[{"id":58087,"uris":["http://zotero.org/users/9607907/items/7FLL36P7"],"itemData":{"id":58087,"type":"article-journal","abstract":"CONTEXT: Assessments of abortion levels and trends by women's age at termination can be used to monitor trends in unintended pregnancy by age and can inform relevant programs and policies.
METHODS: Legal abortion incidence data were compiled from national statistical offices and nationally representative surveys of more than 40 countries where legal abortion is generally available. Age-specific abortion rates and percentage distributions of abortions by age were computed, and trends since 1996 and 2003 were examined. Subregional and regional estimates were developed for geographic areas where the majority of the population was represented by the data.
RESULTS: The median year for the most recent estimates of abortions by woman's age was 2009. Adolescents accounted for a smaller share of abortions than their share of the population in the majority of eligible countries with data. In most countries, the highest age-specific abortion rates and proportions of abortions were among women aged 20-29. Since 1996, adolescent abortion rates have increased the most in Belgium, the Netherlands and Scotland (22-42%), and have decreased the most in Estonia, Hungary, Iceland, Slovakia and Slovenia (40-55%). The proportion of abortions obtained by adolescents was higher in North America (18%) than in Europe overall (11%), although the proportion in Northern Europe (18%) was the same as that in North America.
CONCLUSIONS: Higher abortion rates in particular age-groups probably reflect higher-than-average levels of unmet need for contraception or difficulty using methods consistently and effectively, and a stronger desire to avoid childbearing. Each of the patterns observed has implications for service and information needs within countries.","container-title":"International Perspectives on Sexual and Reproductive Health","DOI":"10.1363/3814312","ISSN":"1944-0405","issue":"3","journalAbbreviation":"Int Perspect Sex Reprod Health","language":"eng","note":"PMID: 23018136","page":"143-153","source":"PubMed","title":"Legal abortion levels and trends by woman's age at termination","volume":"38","author":[{"family":"Sedgh","given":"Gilda"},{"family":"Bankole","given":"Akinrinola"},{"family":"Singh","given":"Susheela"},{"family":"Eilers","given":"Michelle"}],"issued":{"date-parts":[["2012",9]]}}}],"schema":"https://github.com/citation-style-language/schema/raw/master/csl-citation.json"}

w:r.w:delText: analyzed data from 2000-2015 in selected low- and middle-income countries and found that abortion rates were highest among
women in their twenties, who also represented a disproportionately large share of abortions relative to their population size in these countries
w:r.w:delInstrText:
ADDIN ZOTERO_ITEM CSL_CITATION {"citationID":"qecArgDF","properties":{"formattedCitation":"(Chae et al. 2017)","plainCitation":"(Chae et al. 2017)","noteIndex":0},"citationItems":[{"id":58021,"uris":["http://zotero.org/users/9607907/items/ZXQ7HWCY"],"itemData":{"id":58021,"type":"article-journal","abstract":"BACKGROUND: In 2010-2014, approximately 86% of abortions took place in low- and middle-income countries (LMICs). Although abortion incidence varies minimally across geographical regions, it varies widely by subregion and within countries by subgroups of women. Differential abortion levels stem from variation in the level of unintended pregnancies and in the likelihood that women with unintended pregnancies obtain abortions.
OBJECTIVES: To examine the characteristics of women obtaining induced abortions in LMICs.
METHODS: We use data from official statistics, population-based surveys, and abortion patient surveys to examine variation in the percentage distribution of abortions and abortion rates by age at abortion, marital status, parity, wealth, education, and residence. We analyze data from five countries in Africa, 13 in Asia, eight in Europe, and two in Latin America and the Caribbean (LAC).
RESULTS: Women across all sociodemographic subgroups obtain abortions. In most countries, women aged 20-29 obtained the highest proportion of abortions, and while adolescents obtained a substantial fraction of abortions, they do not make up a disproportionate share. Region-specific patterns were observed in the distribution of abortions by parity. In many countries, a higher fraction of abortions occurred among women of high socioeconomic status, as measured by wealth status, educational attainment, and urban residence. Due to limited data on marital status, it is unknown whether married or unmarried women make up a larger share of abortions.
CONCLUSIONS: These findings help to identify subgroups of women with disproportionate levels of abortion, and can inform policies and programs to reduce the incidence of unintended pregnancies; and in LMICs that have restrictive abortion laws, these findings can also inform policies to minimize the consequences of unsafe abortion and motivate liberalization of abortion laws. Program planners, policymakers, and advocates can use this information to improve access to safe abortion services, postabortion care, and contraceptive services.","container-title":"PloS One","DOI":"10.1371/journal.pone.0172976","ISSN":"1932-6203","issue":"3","journalAbbreviation":"PLoS One","language":"eng","note":"PMID: 28355285
PMCID: PMC5371299","page":"e0172976","source":"PubMed","title":"Characteristics of women obtaining induced abortions in selected low- and middle-income countries","volume":"12","author":[{"family":"Chae","given":"Sophia"},{"family":"Desai","given":"Sheila"},{"family":"Crowell","given":"Marjorie"},{"family":"Sedgh","given":"Gilda"},{"family":"Singh","given":"Susheela"}],"issued":{"date-parts":[["2017"]]}}}],"schema":"https://github.com/citation-style-language/schema/raw/master/csl-citation.json"}

w:r.w:t: In recent decades, several factors influencing women’s age at the time of abortion have seen notable shifts worldwide. While many countries
like Mexico and Ireland
have liberalized their abortion laws and expanded access to abortion, some like the United States (US) and Poland have moved toward more regressive and restrictive laws

PMCID: PMC5371299","page":"e0172976","source":"PubMed","title":"Characteristics of women obtaining induced abortions in selected low- and middle-income countries","volume":"12","author":[{"family":"Chae","given":"Sophia"},{"family":"Desai","given":"Sheila"},{"family":"Crowell","given":"Marjorie"},{"family":"Sedgh","given":"Gilda"},{"family":"Singh","given":"Susheela"}],"issued":{"date-parts":[["2017"]]}}},{"id":58076,"uris":["http://zotero.org/users/9607907/items/TL8M44ZF"],"itemData":{"id":58076,"type":"article-journal","abstract":"BACKGROUND: Examining the distribution of abortions by method of abortion and gestational age at time of termination provides insight about the options women may have to terminate their pregnancies. Comparing these distributions across countries and over time is an important step toward understanding the factors that can drive these distributions, including regulations and practices related to the provision of abortion services, and women's preferences and needs.
METHODS: We sought official statistics on gestational age and method of abortion for all high-income countries with liberal abortion laws. For the 24 high-income countries with available data, we calculated percentage distributions of abortions by gestational age of pregnancy and method of abortion for 2017 or the most recent year for which data were available, and assessed trends in the preceding 10 years whenever possible.
RESULTS: Medication (or medical) abortion accounts for at least half of all abortions in the majority of countries. In the majority of countries over 90% of all abortions were completed before 13 weeks, and more than two-thirds of abortions occurred before the first 9
weeks of gestation. Over the past 10 years there has been an increase in both the proportion of abortions that were medication abortions and the proportion that were obtained before 9

weeks gestation.\nCONCLUSIONS: These findings highlight changes in abortion provision in the past decade. w:r.w:instrText: ADDIN ZOTERO_ITEM CSL_CITATION {"citationID":"Me5cpIT6","properties":{"formattedCitation":"(Center for Reproductive Rights, n.d.)","plainCitation":"(Center for Reproductive Rights, n.d.)","noteIndex":0},"citationItems":[{"id":58678,"uris":["http://zotero.org/users/9607907/items/GH9RABB7"],"itemData":{"id":58678,"type":"webpage","container-title":"Center for Reproductive Rights","language":"English","title":"World's Abortion Laws","URL":"https://reproductiverights.org/maps/world-abortion-laws/"}}],"schema":"https://github.com/citation-style-language/schema/raw/master/csl-citation.json"}

w:r.w:t: (Center for Reproductive Rights, n.d.)
We identified 25 countries with publicly available official statistics on abortions by age, published on an annual basis (
Table XX
). Data were generally available in counts, though in a few cases they were only available in percentages or rates. If such data were not available online,
we contacted agencies

directly and asked representatives to complete the Guttmacher Abortion Questionnaire (ABQ), a standardized questionnaire on the incidence of legally induced abortions by selected characteristics of women, including age. The ABQ has been distributed to and completed by in-country experts since
the early 2000s.

We contacted individuals from agencies in 22 countries for which we already had ABQ data for previous years. These contacts included a mix of Guttmacher Institute collaborators from prior studies, new contacts identified through web searches, and individuals recommended by other researchers. We requested that they complete the ABQ for the years 2017 to 2023, and we received 11 complete questionnaires. In addition to publicly available and Guttmacher Abortion Questionnaire data, we extracted information on abortions by age for 30 countries through the United Nations Statistics Division’ Demographic Yearbook (UNSD) collection.

Population data

Study sample selection

We identified 29 countries that have estimates for which we could reasonably expect to include at least 90% of all abortions in that country. We determined this based on information provided in reports published by countries, or by information provided to the Guttmacher Institute by in-country experts.
Two of these countries (Hungary and Bulgaria) include spontaneous abortions in their counts of abortions by age.

We exclude 32 countries that do not meet this criteria from the main analysis as we cannot assume that unaccounted abortions are evenly distributed between age groups and therefore cannot produce reliable estimates of percentage distributions by age groups or age-specific abortion rates (
Table XX

). Given our focus on observing time trends, we excluded two countries that did not have at least four data points from distinct 5-year time periods since 2000. Our final sample included data from 29 countries.
Our final sample included data from 29 countries.
Twenty-four of the
se countries
are
in Europe. The remaining five countries are located in Northern America, Asia, and Oceania (
Table x

). Data were available for the entire study period in all countries except Denmark, Portugal and Singapore. For Denmark and Singapore, the most recent data year is 2015, while data for Portugal are available only from 2010 onward. Therefore, trends observed in these countries compared to the others should be interpreted with caution.
Analysis
Selection of data sources and years
To generate a broad picture of trends in abortions by age for each country, we aimed to have data
representative

of 2000, 2005, 2010, 2015, 2020, and the latest year of available data (generally 2022, 2023, or 2024). If data from these years were not available or the data was poor quality, we selected one data point in the following time periods: 1997-2002, 2003-2007, 2008-2012, 2013-2017, 2018-2021, and 2022-2027, closest to the representative year and/or best available data from the time period for the year. For most countries, we had more than one data point within a given period, and in some cases, we had data from more than one data source for a given year. As such, we considered several facets of the data to choose the best available data.

To determine which data source and year to select for a given country and period, we developed an algorithm that sorts and selects data sources and years based on the following criteria (in order of importance):
Data source type (primary: official statistics/country report/ABQ vs secondary: UNSD)
Data classification, according to Bearak and colleagues’ protocol to classify abortion data,
w:r.w:instrText: ADDIN ZOTERO_ITEM CSL_CITATION {"citationID":"o44TPSKV","properties":{"formattedCitation":"(Bearak et al. 2019)","plainCitation":"(Bearak et al. 2019)","noteIndex":0},"citationItems":[{"id":58679,"uris":["http://zotero.org/users/9607907/items/VTIZ5D3Z"],"itemData":{"id":58679,"type":"article-journal","container-title":"Reproductive Health","DOI":"10.1186/s12978-019-0682-0","ISSN":"1742-4755","issue":"1","journalAbbreviation":"Reprod Health","language":"en","page":"36","source":"DOI.org (Crossref)","title":"Pregnancies, abortions, and pregnancy intentions: a protocol for modeling and reporting global, regional and country estimates","title-short":"Pregnancies, abortions, and pregnancy intentions","volume":"16","author":[{"family":"Bearak","given":"Jonathan Marc"},{"family":"Popinchalk","given":"Anna"},{"family":"Sedgh","given":"Gilda"},{"family":"Ganatra","given":"Bela"},{"family":"Moller","given":"Ann-Beth"},{"family":"Tunçalp","given":"Özge"},{"family":"Alkema","given":"Leontine"}],"issued":{"date-parts":[["2019",12]]}}}],"schema":"https://github.com/citation-style-language/schema/raw/master/csl-citation.json"}

w:r.w:t: (Bearak et al. 2019)
Granularity of the age groups (i.e., availability of 5-year age groups versus 10-year age groups)
Recency of the data source
Format of the age data (counts, percentages, rates)
Distance from the desired year

Based on these criteria, the selected year within a period for each country was not always the exact representative year. When possible, we ensured that all data points for a given country were from the same type of data source. However, if the desired

data source did not cover the entire study period, we used an alternate source to complete the missing years so long as the alternate source was close enough in estimation to the desired source. For example, if the country had data from both the desired and alternate data source for a different year, we calculated the differences in the estimates for that year. If the estimates were identical or the differences were no greater than
X%

in each age group, we used the alternate data source to complete the data points missing in the original source. When we did not have overlapping years to compare data sources, we did not use an alternate data source to complete missing years. The only countries that had a combination of data sources across the study period were Mongolia and Slovakia, each having a combination of ABQ and UNSD data.
Age groups

All countries included in the main analysis have data available for the same 5-year age groups from ages 20 to 39. However, groups for ages below 20 and above 40 vary widely between countries. Due to these variations, we selected “15 to 19” and “40 plus” as the youngest and eldest age groups for cross-country comparisons. Some countries use “under 20” as their youngest age group, and percentage distributions and rates for this group are presented with the “15 to 19” group. Breakdowns by more granular age groups in the adolescent range will also be shown when available. Counts for abortions by age in the UK were generated by summing the counts in England and Wales, Northern Ireland, and Scotland.
Measures

We examined three measures that provide different perspectives on the association between abortion and women’s ages: the percentage distribution of abortion across age groups, age-specific abortion rates per 1,000 women, and the average annual percentage change in age-specific and overall abortion rates across the study period. Percentage distributions show how abortions are distributed across age groups irrespective of total abortion numbers and their trends over time. Unlike percentage distributions, age-specific rates indicate how common abortion is within each age group and allow for comparisons between age groups in the probability of
obtaining an abortion
. The average annual percentage changes capture trends in abortion rates across the study period and allow for cross-country comparisons.

First, we calculated the percentage distributions of abortions in each age group, across all countries and years. Some countries reported counts of abortions for which the age of the woman was not stated or unknown, and we reported these counts as their own category in the percentage distributions. We calculated percentage distributions in age groups by dividing the number of abortions in each age group by the total number of abortions and multiplying the result by 100. Where estimates were already in percentages (e.g. Netherlands 2005), we kept them as is. Where estimates were in rates (e.g. Latvia 2005), we converted the rates back to counts before calculating the percentage distributions.

Then, we calculated age-specific abortion rates per 1,000 women by dividing the number of abortions in each age group by the number of women in the population in that age group and then multiplying the result by 1,000. For rates among women aged under 20, we used the female population aged 15 to 19 as the denominator. Fourteen countries included in our analysis provided abortion counts under the age of 15, and these account for less than 1% of the total number of abortions in any given year. Of the four countries who provided additional breakdowns by individual ages under 15, 80-90% occur at age 14. Therefore, while abortions under the age of 15 do occur, including the population aged 10-14 in the denominator for rates among women aged under 20 may severely underestimate the rates in this group. On the other end, we used the female population aged 40-49 as the denominator used to calculate rates among women aged 40 or more

as the number of abortions in women aged 50 and above is less than 0.1% of total abortions in countries where this data is available. For the overall abortion rates, we used the female population aged 15-49 as the denominator. In countries and years with non-negligeable numbers of abortions where age was unknown or not stated (Table
XX
), the age-specific rates indicate
the minimum number of abortions within the age groups
since we cannot assume that the missing data are distributed evenly between age groups.

For countries including spontaneous abortions in their counts of abortions by age, we implemented an adjustment to the age-specific total abortion rates to estimate age-specific induced abortion rates and present both. Given,
Pregnancy rate = Total abortion rate + Birth rate
and we assume that spontaneous abortions
are around 10% of induced abortions and 20% of births (source),
Pregnancy rate = (1.1 * Induced abortion rate) + (1.2 * Birth rate)
we can rearrange
algebraically to isolate
the i
nduced abortion rate
Total abortion rate + Birth rate = (1.1 * Induced abortion rate) + 1.2 (Birth rate)
Induced abortion rate = (Total abortion rate – 0.2 Birth rate) / 1.1

w:r.w:delText: In the absence of data on spontaneous abortion

w:r.w:t: we estimated that
approximately 20% of births represent the number of pregnancies that would end in spontaneous abortion.

We therefore subtracted 20% of the age-specific fertility rates from the corresponding age-specific rates, then divided the adjusted rates by 1.1 to convert the estimate from total pregnancies to induced abortions, based on the coefficient for induced abortions in the pregnancy equation above.
This adjustment assumes that the relationship between abortions, births, and spontaneous abortions is consistent across age groups, though we acknowledge this may not be the case.

Lastly, we calculated the average annual percentage change in age-specific abortion rates across each country’s analytical time period. Our formula for calculating average annual percentage changes is the following:
(age-specific rate in latest year / age-specific rate in earliest year) ^ (1 / latest year – earliest year)
Results
asars.xlsx
percent_distributions.xlsx
ann_perc_change.xlsx

In the early- to mid-2020s, adolescent abortions accounted for the smallest share of abortions in 13 countries, ranging from 3.3% in Belarus to 15.3% in Greenland. Abortion among women aged 20 to 24 ranged from 13% in Belarus to 26% in the United Kingdom. Abortions among women aged 25 to 29 and 30 to 34 each accounted for a fifth to a quarter of all abortions across almost all countries. Abortions among women aged 35 to 39 ranged from 10% in Greenland to 24% in Belarus. Women aged 40 or more accounted for the smallest share of abortions in 16 countries, ranging from 2% in Greenland to 11% in Belarus.

In the early 2000s, abortions among adolescents ranged from 7% in Mongolia to 26% in Iceland. Abortions among women aged 20 to 24 ranged from 13% in Belarus to 28% in the US. Abortions among women age 25 to 29 and 30 to 34 each accounted for a fifth to a quarter of all abortions. Women aged 40 or more accounted for the smallest share of abortions in all but two countries (Lithuania and Mongolia), ranging from 2% in Greenland to 10% in Mongolia.

Overall, the distribution of abortions by age shifted markedly between the early 2000s and the early 2020s, with higher proportions of abortions increasingly concentrated among older age groups. In all countries, the percentage of abortions attributable to adolescents declined and was below 10% in 20 of the 29 countries by the early- to mid-2020s. In all but two countries (Denmark and Portugal), the percentage of abortions attributable to women aged 20 to 24 declined as well. The share of all abortions attributable to women aged 25 to 29 increased in two-thirds of the countries, and the percentage distribution of abortions among women aged 30 to 34, 35 to 39, and 40 or more increased in all but two countries (Greenland and Denmark, Portugal and Denmark, and Mongolia and Hungary, respectively).
Shifts in the distribution of abortions among adolescents reflect changes in abortion rates in this age group, which have decreased across all countries

between the early 2000s and early- to mid-2020s. Beyond the adolescent range, trends in the distribution of abortions do not necessarily reflect changes in rates. Among women aged 20 to 24, decreased percentage distributions were not paired with decreasing abortion rates in Mongolia, England and Wales, Scotland, Spain, Belgium, France, and the Netherlands, where abortion rates were higher in the early- to mid-2020s than they were in the early 2000s. These reverse trends were also observed among women aged 25 to 29, where in Mongolia, Spain, and Switzerland, rates increased but the distribution of abortions

decreased. Within this age group, abortion rates decreased in New Zealand, Singapore, Hungary, the US, Finland, Norway, Slovenia, and Germany, but the percentage of all abortions attributable to this age group increased. Among women aged 30 to 34, 35 to 39, and 40 or more, age-specific abortion rates increased in approximately half of the countries, but percentage distributions increased in almost all countries.

Overall, the steepest declines in rates were observed among adolescents, with average annual percentage changes in rates reaching -8% in Latvia, -10% in Lithuania, and -11% in Singapore. The largest increases in age-specific abortion rates reached only around 3% annually and occurred primarily among women aged 30 or older in Western and Northern Europe.

Age-specific patterns varied by region. All Western European countries experienced increases across age groups older than 15 to 19, with the sole exception of German women aged 20 to 24 and 25 to 29. At the beginning of the study period, age-specific and overall abortion rates in Western Europe were amongst the lowest of all countries included in the analysis. By the end of the study period, they had converged to levels similar to Eastern and Southern European countries. Homogenous regional trends were also observed in Eastern Europe, where abortion rates declined consistently across all countries and age groups. The Baltic states (Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania), along with the US and Singapore, similarly experienced decreases across all age groups. By contrast, the Nordic countries (Denmark, Finland, Iceland, Norway, Sweden) displayed more heterogenous patterns, with only two consistent trends: declining rates among adolescents and increasing rates among women aged 40 or older.

Six countries experiencing overall decreases in abortion rates between the early 2000s and early- to mid-2020s (Finland, Iceland, New Zealand, Norway, Slovenia, US) have experienced increases in overall rates in the most recent years. Four of these countries experienced increases among women aged 15 to 19 and four saw increases among women aged 20 to 24 and 25 to 29 despite overall decreases in these age groups since the early 2000s.

w:r.w:t: Discussion
In the countries included
in our analysis, we found that distributions of abortions and age-specific abortion rates have shifted markedly in the last two
decades

. Notably, the proportion of abortions attributable to adolescents and abortion rates among adolescents have decreased, even in countries with rising overall abortion rates. Among women aged 20 or more, variations were observed between countries and regions. In Western European countries, rates increased across all age groups beyond the adolescent range. Conversely, Eastern European countries and the Baltic states experienced decreases across all age groups. Other regions, such as the Nordic states, experienced more heterogenous shifts. Despite these variations, women in their twenties and early thirties consistently experienced the highest abortion rates in almost all countries across the study period. In addition, the magnitude of rate decreases was generally larger than that of increases.
Our study provides continuing evidence that abortion rates are generally highest among women in their twenties, as observed by earlier assessments of abortions by women’s ages

However, we observed a shift in rates within women in their twenties, with the highest rates shifting from women in their early twenties to women in their late twenties in five countries (Norway, Sweden, Belgium, France, Germany). In addition, abortion rates shifted from being highest among women in their twenties to women in their early thirties in another four countries (Mongolia, Belarus, Lithuania, the Netherlands) by the early- to mid-2020s.

Shifts in contraceptive behaviors are important drivers in abortion incidence and may partly explain some trends observed in our analysis. In Europe, modern contraceptive use has varied widely due to social and political factors, particularly between Western and Central/Eastern European countries that were part of the Soviet bloc. Before the Soviet Union’s collapse in 1991, limited access to modern contraceptive methods in these countries led to heavy reliance on traditional methods such as withdrawal, and abortion was also a socially accepted recourse in case of contraceptive failure

w:r.w:t: (Spoorenberg et al. 2024)

. These declining fertility rates, coupled with the declining adolescent abortion rates observed in our analysis, suggest a broader decline in adolescent pregnancy rates. This pattern may be explained by the increased use of modern contraceptive methods among adolescents and young women globally since the early 2000s
w:r.w:instrText: ADDIN ZOTERO_ITEM CSL_CITATION {"citationID":"CWNQ41YT","properties":{"formattedCitation":"({\\i{}World Family Planning 2022} 2022)","plainCitation":"(World Family Planning 2022 2022)","noteIndex":0},"citationItems":[{"id":58187,"uris":["http://zotero.org/users/9607907/items/HDMBDGTV"],"itemData":{"id":58187,"type":"book","abstract":"\"Contraception assists individuals and couples to achieve their reproductive goals and enables them to exercise the right to have children by choice. It presents trends in contraceptive use by type of method, including regional variations in the use of specific methods. w:r.w:t: World Family Planning 2022
. The dynamics of pregnancies, births, and abortions among adolescents and the impact of contraceptive use on these events are further supported by evidence from the US, where experts concluded
that declines in adolescent pregnancy rates are driven by increased and improved contraceptive use
w:r.w:instrText: ADDIN ZOTERO_ITEM CSL_CITATION {"citationID":"f0KelCvh","properties":{"formattedCitation":"(Lindberg et al. 2016)","plainCitation":"(Lindberg et al. 2016)","noteIndex":0},"citationItems":[{"id":58916,"uris":["http://zotero.org/groups/6299705/items/I5X8L2MS"],"itemData":{"id":58916,"type":"article-journal","container-title":"Journal of Adolescent Health","DOI":"10.1016/j.jadohealth.2016.06.024","ISSN":"1054139X","issue":"5","journalAbbreviation":"Journal of Adolescent Health","language":"en","page":"577-583","source":"DOI.org (Crossref)","title":"Understanding the Decline in Adolescent Fertility in the United States, 2007–2012","volume":"59","author":[{"family":"Lindberg","given":"Laura"},{"family":"Santelli","given":"John"},{"family":"Desai","given":"Sheila"}],"issued":{"date-parts":[["2016",11]]}}}],"schema":"https://github.com/citation-style-language/schema/raw/master/csl-citation.json"}

w:r.w:t: (Lindberg et al. 2016)

Other individual-level factors may also contribute to shifts in overall and age-specific abortion incidence. Among the 38 OECD (Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development) member countries, 24 of which are included in our analysis, delayed childbearing and rising age at first birth have been observed over the last two decades. With many countries facing rising financial instability, increasing costs of raising children, and growing housing insecurity, the transition into parenthood may be increasingly complicated for younger people
w:r.w:instrText: ADDIN ZOTERO_ITEM CSL_CITATION {"citationID":"4AylyXb3","properties":{"formattedCitation":"(OECD 2024)","plainCitation":"(OECD 2024)","noteIndex":0},"citationItems":[{"id":58923,"uris":["http://zotero.org/groups/6299705/items/AS5RU2C5"],"itemData":{"id":58923,"type":"book","collection-title":"Society at a Glance","ISBN":"978-92-64-32418-3","language":"en","note":"DOI: 10.1787/918d8db3-en","publisher":"OECD Publishing","source":"DOI.org (Crossref)","title":"Society at a Glance 2024: OECD Social Indicators","title-short":"Society at a Glance 2024","URL":"https://www.oecd.org/en/publications/society-at-a-glance-2024_918d8db3-en.html","author":[{"literal":"OECD"}],"accessed":{"date-parts":[["2025",12,3]]},"issued":{"date-parts":[["2024",6,20]]}}}],"schema":"https://github.com/citation-style-language/schema/raw/master/csl-citation.json"}

w:r.w:t: (OECD 2024)

. These delays in childbearing may in part explain the increases in the distribution and incidence of abortions among women in their late twenties and early thirties—in the mid-range of their reproductive years—observed in more than half the countries included in our analysis. In the UK, for example, the ongoing cost of living crisis and resulting increased financial pressures on households has been cited as one of the reasons why an individual may choose to obtain an abortion
w:r.w:instrText: ADDIN ZOTERO_ITEM CSL_CITATION {"citationID":"oSg5QFYp","properties":{"formattedCitation":"(MSI Reproductive Choices 2023)","plainCitation":"(MSI Reproductive Choices 2023)","noteIndex":0},"citationItems":[{"id":58930,"uris":["http://zotero.org/groups/6299705/items/KZUAKK62"],"itemData":{"id":58930,"type":"webpage","container-title":"MSI Reproductive Choices","language":"English","title":"Why is the abortion rate rising?","URL":"https://www.msichoices.org.uk/news/why-is-the-abortion-rate-rising/","author":[{"family":"MSI Reproductive Choices","given":""}],"issued":{"date-parts":[["2023",6,30]]}}}],"schema":"https://github.com/citation-style-language/schema/raw/master/csl-citation.json"}

w:r.w:t: (MSI Reproductive Choices 2023)
Abortion incidence

may also be affected by country-level policies impacting availability and access to abortion services. In Europe, in the last 10 years, 12 countries included in this analysis have implemented reforms designed to improve access to abortion. Finland and Iceland legalized abortion upon request; Denmark, Estonia, France, Finland, Germany, the Netherlands, Norway, and Spain repealed some of their procedural barriers; and France, Lithuania, the Netherlands, and the UK expanded access to medication abortion
w:r.w:instrText: ADDIN ZOTERO_ITEM CSL_CITATION {"citationID":"JgtYQRqu","properties":{"formattedCitation":"(Center for Reproductive Rights 2025)","plainCitation":"(Center for Reproductive Rights 2025)","noteIndex":0},"citationItems":[{"id":58834,"uris":["http://zotero.org/groups/6299705/items/TE8CAKVA"],"itemData":{"id":58834,"type":"report","publisher":"Center for Reproductive Rights","title":"Europe Abortion Laws 2025: Policies, Progress and Challenges","URL":"https://reproductiverights.org/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/Europe-Abortion-Laws-2025.pdf","author":[{"family":"Center for Reproductive Rights","given":""}],"issued":{"date-parts":[["2025",9,23]]}}}],"schema":"https://github.com/citation-style-language/schema/raw/master/csl-citation.json"}

w:r.w:t: (Center for Reproductive Rights 2025)

. However, these positive reforms are counterbalanced by negative actions. In the UK for example, pressures on the National Health Service and substantial budget cuts to reproductive health services (disproportionately impacting the poorer parts of the country) have made access to contraceptive services more difficult, which may in turn impact abortion incidence
w:r.w:instrText: ADDIN ZOTERO_ITEM CSL_CITATION {"citationID":"AfWkmwAk","properties":{"formattedCitation":"(MSI Reproductive Choices 2023)","plainCitation":"(MSI Reproductive Choices 2023)","noteIndex":0},"citationItems":[{"id":58930,"uris":["http://zotero.org/groups/6299705/items/KZUAKK62"],"itemData":{"id":58930,"type":"webpage","container-title":"MSI Reproductive Choices","language":"English","title":"Why is the abortion rate rising?","URL":"https://www.msichoices.org.uk/news/why-is-the-abortion-rate-rising/","author":[{"family":"MSI Reproductive Choices","given":""}],"issued":{"date-parts":[["2023",6,30]]}}}],"schema":"https://github.com/citation-style-language/schema/raw/master/csl-citation.json"}

w:r.w:t: (MSI Reproductive Choices 2023)

. While there have generally been efforts to improve access to abortion services across Europe, it is important to acknowledge that access to abortion in Europe is fragile: seven European countries introducing regressive policies in the last decade (Armenia, Georgia, Hungary, Italy, Moldova, Poland, and Russia) and five countries maintaining restrictive or near-total
bans on abortion (Andorra, Malta, Liechtenstein, Poland, and Monaco)
w:r.w:instrText: ADDIN ZOTERO_ITEM CSL_CITATION {"citationID":"kSzBRRcr","properties":{"formattedCitation":"(Center for Reproductive Rights 2025; Miani and Razum 2021)","plainCitation":"(Center for Reproductive Rights 2025; Miani and Razum 2021)","noteIndex":0},"citationItems":[{"id":58834,"uris":["http://zotero.org/groups/6299705/items/TE8CAKVA"],"itemData":{"id":58834,"type":"report","publisher":"Center for Reproductive Rights","title":"Europe Abortion Laws 2025: Policies, Progress and Challenges","URL":"https://reproductiverights.org/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/Europe-Abortion-Laws-2025.pdf","author":[{"family":"Center for Reproductive Rights","given":""}],"issued":{"date-parts":[["2025",9,23]]}}},{"id":58925,"uris":["http://zotero.org/groups/6299705/items/EHQK4J3M"],"itemData":{"id":58925,"type":"article-journal","container-title":"The Lancet","DOI":"10.1016/S0140-6736(21)01225-3","ISSN":"01406736","issue":"10299","journalAbbreviation":"The Lancet","language":"en","page":"485","source":"DOI.org (Crossref)","title":"The fragility of abortion access in Europe: a public health crisis in the making","title-short":"The fragility of abortion access in Europe","volume":"398","author":[{"family":"Miani","given":"Céline"},{"family":"Razum","given":"Oliver"}],"issued":{"date-parts":[["2021",8]]}}}],"schema":"https://github.com/citation-style-language/schema/raw/master/csl-citation.json"}

w:r.w:t: (Center for Reproductive Rights 2025; Miani and Razum 2021)

As noted in our findings, the US—along with New Zealand and a few Northern European countries—seems to have experienced a stop or even slight reversal in its sustained declines in age-specific abortion rates in recent years. Evidence from the US through 2023 found that the total number of abortions in the US and national abortion rate increased between 2020 and 2023, the highest estimates measured in the US in over a decade, confirming the reversal of the declining trends from 2000 to 2020 observed in our analysis

. In 2024, these numbers remained relatively stable, increasing by one percent

w:r.w:t: (Guttmacher Institute et al. 2025)
. These increases, particularly since the 2022
Dobbs

decision and the increasingly restrictive abortion policies in many states, may in part be explained by increased access in more protective states through expanded telehealth services, increased financial support for abortion seekers, and implementation of other protective policies. These trends in the US highlight the critical role of country- and state-level policies affecting access to abortion on incidence

w:r.w:t: (Guttmacher Institute et al. 2025)

This study is subject to limitations. As a descriptive rather than an inferential study, we did not explore associations or correlations between age-specific abortion rates and factors that explain the shifts and variations observed through our analysis. By examining abortion rates only by the age of women, we were also not able to identify potential inequities between population subgroups within age groups. Moreover, limited availability and quality of abortion data by age in many countries and regions narrowed the geographic representation of the study (all but two countries in our analysis are high-income countries, according to the World Bank classification)

w:r.w:t: (Metreau et al. 2025)

. We were therefore not able to examine trends in countries where abortion is restricted or where abortion data is incomplete. In 2020, Bearak and colleagues found no evidence that abortion rates are lower in countries where abortion is restricted, highlighting the importance of collecting data in these countries to better understand global abortion trends
w:r.w:instrText: ADDIN ZOTERO_ITEM CSL_CITATION {"citationID":"qtSXwAjK","properties":{"formattedCitation":"(Bearak et al. 2020b)","plainCitation":"(Bearak et al. 2020b)","noteIndex":0},"citationItems":[{"id":58815,"uris":["http://zotero.org/groups/6299705/items/YQZLF59H"],"itemData":{"id":58815,"type":"article-journal","container-title":"The Lancet Global Health","DOI":"10.1016/S2214-109X(20)30315-6","ISSN":"2214109X","issue":"9","journalAbbreviation":"The Lancet Global Health","language":"en","page":"e1152-e1161","source":"DOI.org (Crossref)","title":"Unintended pregnancy and abortion by income, region, and the legal status of abortion: estimates from a comprehensive model for 1990–2019","title-short":"Unintended pregnancy and abortion by income, region, and the legal status of abortion","volume":"8","author":[{"family":"Bearak","given":"Jonathan"},{"family":"Popinchalk","given":"Anna"},{"family":"Ganatra","given":"Bela"},{"family":"Moller","given":"Ann-Beth"},{"family":"Tunçalp","given":"Özge"},{"family":"Beavin","given":"Cynthia"},{"family":"Kwok","given":"Lorraine"},{"family":"Alkema","given":"Leontine"}],"issued":{"date-parts":[["2020",9]]}}}],"schema":"https://github.com/citation-style-language/schema/raw/master/csl-citation.json"}

w:r.w:t: (Bearak et al. 2020b)

This study examines trends in age-specific abortion rates in the last two decades in countries with complete data. Our findings highlight notable shifts in the distribution and incidence of abortions across age groups, with substantial declines among adolescents contrasted by increases among women in the middle and nearing the end of their reproductive years. Concurrent global shifts in contraceptive behaviors, fertility planning, educational attainment, and policies regarding abortion highlight the complex interplay of factors impacting abortion incidence by age and the need for further investigation. These findings also suggest several directions for future research that could help shape policies and programs targeted toward specific age groups. Exploring age-specific patterns in methods of abortion and gestational age may provide further insights into the dynamics behind age-specific trends in abortion
w:r.w:instrText: ADDIN ZOTERO_ITEM CSL_CITATION {"citationID":"4rHis53x","properties":{"formattedCitation":"(Popinchalk and Sedgh 2019)","plainCitation":"(Popinchalk and Sedgh 2019)","noteIndex":0},"citationItems":[{"id":58076,"uris":["http://zotero.org/users/9607907/items/TL8M44ZF"],"itemData":{"id":58076,"type":"article-journal","abstract":"BACKGROUND: Examining the distribution of abortions by method of abortion and gestational age at time of termination provides insight about the options women may have to terminate their pregnancies. Comparing these distributions across countries and over time is an important step toward understanding the factors that can drive these distributions, including regulations and practices related to the provision of abortion services, and women's preferences and needs.\nMETHODS: We sought official statistics on gestational age and method of abortion for all high-income countries with liberal abortion laws. For the 24 high-income countries with available data, we calculated percentage distributions of abortions by gestational age of pregnancy and method of abortion for 2017 or the most recent year for which data were available, and assessed trends in the preceding 10 years whenever possible.\nRESULTS: Medication (or medical) abortion accounts for at least half of all abortions in the majority of countries. In the majority of countries over 90% of all abortions were completed before 13 weeks, and more than two-thirds of abortions occurred before the first 9
weeks of gestation. Over the past 10 years there has been an increase in both the proportion of abortions that were medication abortions and the proportion that were obtained before 9

weeks gestation.\nCONCLUSIONS: These findings highlight changes in abortion provision in the past decade. More research is needed to understand whether the observed distributions are a function of women's preferences or of barriers to the timing and type of care they would prefer.","container-title":"BMJ sexual & reproductive health","DOI":"10.1136/bmjsrh-2018-200149","ISSN":"2515-2009","issue":"2","journalAbbreviation":"BMJ Sex Reprod Health","language":"eng","note":"PMID: 30962177\nPMCID: PMC6579506","page":"95-103","source":"PubMed","title":"Trends in the method and gestational age of abortion in high-income countries","volume":"45","author":[{"family":"Popinchalk","given":"Anna"},{"family":"Sedgh","given":"Gilda"}],"issued":{"date-parts":[["2019",4,8]]}}}],"schema":"https://github.com/citation-style-language/schema/raw/master/csl-citation.json"}

w:r.w:t: (Popinchalk and Sedgh 2019)
. In addition, examining age-specific patterns in existing indicators of reproductive autonomy, such as the conditional
unintended pregnancy rate, would enhance our understanding of women’s ability to achieve their reproductive preferences
w:r.w:instrText: ADDIN ZOTERO_ITEM CSL_CITATION {"citationID":"mhcxV5V0","properties":{"formattedCitation":"(Bearak et al. 2023)","plainCitation":"(Bearak et al. 2023)","noteIndex":0},"citationItems":[{"id":48732,"uris":["http://zotero.org/groups/2295646/items/B6HTIKW7"],"itemData":{"id":48732,"type":"article-journal","abstract":"Since childbearing desires, and trends in these desires, differ across populations, the inclusion of women who want to become pregnant in the denominator for unintended pregnancy rates complicates interpretation of intercountry differences and trends over time. To address this limitation, we propose a rate that is the ratio of the number of unintended pregnancies to the number of women wanting to avoid pregnancy; we term these conditional rates. We computed conditional unintended pregnancy rates for five-year periods from 1990 to 2019. In 2015-2019, these conditional rates per 1,000 women per year wanting to avoid pregnancy ranged from 35 in Western Europe to 258 in Middle Africa. Rates with all women of reproductive age in the denominator have concealed stark global disparities in the ability of women to avoid unintended pregnancies, and they have understated progress in regions where the fraction of women wanting to avoid pregnancy has increased.","container-title":"Studies in family planning","DOI":"10.1111/sifp.12234","ISSN":"1728-4465","issue":"1","language":"eng","license":"cc by","note":"PMID: 36811721","page":"265-280","source":"Europe PMC","title":"Alignment between Desires and Outcomes among Women Wanting to Avoid Pregnancy: A Global Comparative Study of \"Conditional\" Unintended Pregnancy Rates","title-short":"Alignment between Desires and Outcomes among Women Wanting to Avoid Pregnancy","volume":"54","author":[{"family":"Bearak","given":"Jonathan Marc"},{"family":"Alkema","given":"Leontine"},{"family":"Kantorová","given":"Vladimíra"},{"family":"Casterline","given":"John"}],"issued":{"date-parts":[["2023",3,1]]}}}],"schema":"https://github.com/citation-style-language/schema/raw/master/csl-citation.json"}

Old paragraphs of the intro that we can maybe use in the discussion

Prior global assessments of age patterns of abortion are limited and increasingly outdated. In 1999, Bankole et al analyzed data from 1981-1996 in all countries with available data, and found that globally, abortion rates were generally highest among women in their twenties, but adolescents often accounted for a higher proportion of abortions per known pregnancies than women in their twenties

ADDIN ZOTERO_ITEM CSL_CITATION {"citationID":"V4w5kmO4","properties":{"formattedCitation":"(Sedgh et al. 2012)","plainCitation":"(Sedgh et al. 2012)","noteIndex":0},"citationItems":[{"id":58087,"uris":["http://zotero.org/users/9607907/items/7FLL36P7"],"itemData":{"id":58087,"type":"article-journal","abstract":"CONTEXT: Assessments of abortion levels and trends by women's age at termination can be used to monitor trends in unintended pregnancy by age and can inform relevant programs and policies.
METHODS: Legal abortion incidence data were compiled from national statistical offices and nationally representative surveys of more than 40 countries where legal abortion is generally available. Age-specific abortion rates and percentage distributions of abortions by age were computed, and trends since 1996 and 2003 were examined. Subregional and regional estimates were developed for geographic areas where the majority of the population was represented by the data.
RESULTS: The median year for the most recent estimates of abortions by woman's age was 2009. Adolescents accounted for a smaller share of abortions than their share of the population in the majority of eligible countries with data. In most countries, the highest age-specific abortion rates and proportions of abortions were among women aged 20-29. Since 1996, adolescent abortion rates have increased the most in Belgium, the Netherlands and Scotland (22-42%), and have decreased the most in Estonia, Hungary, Iceland, Slovakia and Slovenia (40-55%). The proportion of abortions obtained by adolescents was higher in North America (18%) than in Europe overall (11%), although the proportion in Northern Europe (18%) was the same as that in North America.
CONCLUSIONS: Higher abortion rates in particular age-groups probably reflect higher-than-average levels of unmet need for contraception or difficulty using methods consistently and effectively, and a stronger desire to avoid childbearing. Each of the patterns observed has implications for service and information needs within countries.","container-title":"International Perspectives on Sexual and Reproductive Health","DOI":"10.1363/3814312","ISSN":"1944-0405","issue":"3","journalAbbreviation":"Int Perspect Sex Reprod Health","language":"eng","note":"PMID: 23018136","page":"143-153","source":"PubMed","title":"Legal abortion levels and trends by woman's age at termination","volume":"38","author":[{"family":"Sedgh","given":"Gilda"},{"family":"Bankole","given":"Akinrinola"},{"family":"Singh","given":"Susheela"},{"family":"Eilers","given":"Michelle"}],"issued":{"date-parts":[["2012",9]]}}}],"schema":"https://github.com/citation-style-language/schema/raw/master/csl-citation.json"}

ADDIN ZOTERO_ITEM CSL_CITATION {"citationID":"qecArgDF","properties":{"formattedCitation":"(Chae et al. 2017)","plainCitation":"(Chae et al. 2017)","noteIndex":0},"citationItems":[{"id":58021,"uris":["http://zotero.org/users/9607907/items/ZXQ7HWCY"],"itemData":{"id":58021,"type":"article-journal","abstract":"BACKGROUND: In 2010-2014, approximately 86% of abortions took place in low- and middle-income countries (LMICs). Although abortion incidence varies minimally across geographical regions, it varies widely by subregion and within countries by subgroups of women. Differential abortion levels stem from variation in the level of unintended pregnancies and in the likelihood that women with unintended pregnancies obtain abortions.
OBJECTIVES: To examine the characteristics of women obtaining induced abortions in LMICs.
METHODS: We use data from official statistics, population-based surveys, and abortion patient surveys to examine variation in the percentage distribution of abortions and abortion rates by age at abortion, marital status, parity, wealth, education, and residence. We analyze data from five countries in Africa, 13 in Asia, eight in Europe, and two in Latin America and the Caribbean (LAC).
RESULTS: Women across all sociodemographic subgroups obtain abortions. In most countries, women aged 20-29 obtained the highest proportion of abortions, and while adolescents obtained a substantial fraction of abortions, they do not make up a disproportionate share. Region-specific patterns were observed in the distribution of abortions by parity. In many countries, a higher fraction of abortions occurred among women of high socioeconomic status, as measured by wealth status, educational attainment, and urban residence. Due to limited data on marital status, it is unknown whether married or unmarried women make up a larger share of abortions.
CONCLUSIONS: These findings help to identify subgroups of women with disproportionate levels of abortion, and can inform policies and programs to reduce the incidence of unintended pregnancies; and in LMICs that have restrictive abortion laws, these findings can also inform policies to minimize the consequences of unsafe abortion and motivate liberalization of abortion laws. Program planners, policymakers, and advocates can use this information to improve access to safe abortion services, postabortion care, and contraceptive services.","container-title":"PloS One","DOI":"10.1371/journal.pone.0172976","ISSN":"1932-6203","issue":"3","journalAbbreviation":"PLoS One","language":"eng","note":"PMID: 28355285

w:r.w:t: (Chae et al. 2017)

Understanding patterns by subgroups, and in particular by age groups, is essential for identifying which populations face the highest burden of unintended pregnancy and abortion, and who would benefit the most from targeted contraceptive and reproductive health resources. A disproportionately high number of abortions in an age group may be indicative that this group has an above-average likelihood of experiencing an unintended pregnancy or of choosing an abortion to end a pregnancy

w:r.w:t: (Bankole et al. 1999)
. Such information can be also used to better understand the factors driving variations in overall abortion incidence, and to craft effective and equitable

reproductive health policies and programs that meet the needs of all individuals. This evidence can also contribute to informed public discourse around abortion and help reduce stigma by providing a data-driven picture of women who obtain abortions.

In several Western European countries and across the UK (including England and Wales, and Scotland), decreases among women aged 15 to 19 were insufficient to offset the increases in older age groups, resulting in a rise in overall abortion rates despite declining youth rates.
